title: I call from a arbitration company about a payday loan saying I will get charged for righting bad checks
question: They said that they are taking my license and that they will stop my Ssi I took out the loan with full intent to pay it back but got over drafted for something and just got over whelmed because I general anxiety disorder
answers:
Payday lenders and their debt collection agencies getting caught again telling lies and harassing their customers and debtors is no surprise to those of us who represent consumers against such illegal practices. It is time to change your phone number, as they will continue to pester you, until they no longer can. It may be worthwhile taking them to court with a consumer attorney at your side, if you know who they are, but some are so low, that they are underground with an untraceable phone line and will not even respond to lawsuits. If you won a debt collection case, you can be awarded your actual damages, statutory damages, costs, and attorney's fees. The limitations period is one year from date of harassment.

The "arbitration company" is a debt collector in disguise. Do not believe anything that this person tells you. Do not waste your time talking with these people.

If they want to sue you, it will be a civil lawsuit. It is not a crime to fail to pay a debt. In a civil suit, the most that the creditor can get is a civil judgment, allowing it to levy on non-exempt property. It is not a court order to pay anything. You person possessions, money and income that you need for "necessities of life" and most government benefits are exempt from levy for a civil judgment That is why payday and short term lenders rarely file civil lawsuits. What they try to do is to scare you into paying them, or to have you "roll over" the loan into a new short term loan.

This "arbitration" company is a scam. If anything they've violated the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act and Rosenthal Act.

It is unlawful and a crime to threaten to charge someone criminally for a civil debt.

It is also unlawful to threaten to cut off someone's public benefits.

When you gave them a check, it was likely post-dated. So you cannot write a "hot check" when the company receiving it knows that its not good on the day it was written.

I would suggest that you get their information and report them to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, and the California Attorney General's Office of the State of California.
